newsitem.title: CHINA: China courts reject American's garbage appeal.
newsitem.headline: China courts reject American's garbage appeal.

text.p: An American businessman has lost his appeal against a 10-year jail sentence imposed by a Chinese court for illegally importing garbage into China, the Liberation Daily reported on Saturday.

William Ping Chen had appealed against the jail term and a fine of 500,000 yuan ($60,000) imposed by Shanghai Number One Intermediate Court last December for smuggling 238 tonnes of garbage and medical waste to Shanghai, it said.
The original court verdict also ordered Chen to be deported, but it was unclear when that was to take effect.
Born in Shanghai, Chen, 56, is a resident of Oakland, California.
Until his arrest last June he was president of Shanghai Tongyi Paper Co Ltd, which had been banned by the Chinese government from importing garbage, it said.

He had listed the imported material as waste paper and mixed paper and had gone ahead with the shipment despite warnings from Shanghai environmental officials and opposition from his Chinese joint-venture partners, the newspaper said.
It said Chen had based his appeal on a claim that he was not the shipper of the garbage and therefore could not be accused of smuggling it into China.
The Shanghai Higher People's Court rejected the claim and upheld the sentence, it said.

Chen's arrest was the climax of an emotional campaign by China, launched in mid-1996, against illegal shipments of U.S. garbage listed as waste paper for recycling but found to contain old clothes, rubber gloves and disposable syringes.
